description: From Middle English chare, variant (due to the verb form charen) of char, cher (“a turn”), from Old English ċierr, ċerr (“a turn, change, time, occasion, affair, business”), from Proto-Germanic *karzijaną (“to turn, sweep”), from Proto-Indo-European *gers- (“to turn, bend”). More at char.

entries.meaning: Alternative form of char ("turn, task, chore, worker").
(Northern England) A narrow lane or passage between houses in a town.

verbs.description: chare (third-person singular simple present chares, present participle charing, simple past and past participle chared)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To work by the day, without being a regularly hired servant; to do small jobs; to char.
